title: Diagnosing Alzheimer's Disease
content: Alzheimer’s disease is both the most common neurodegenerative disease and the most common cause of dementia. The diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease starts with a clinical diagnosis made by a neurologist who assesses various symptoms such as difficulty remembering events, difficulty concentrating, planning or problem solving, confusion with location, temporal confusion, and language problems. There may be some sort of mental status exam or neuropsychological tests. There will also be some lab tests done to rule out other causes. The diagnosis isn't definitively made until an autopsy. However, there are other biomarkers that are increasing in the sensitivity for this, such as the ability to look at serum, amyloid, and tau.

title: Biomarkers for Alzheimer's Disease
content: Biomarkers like amyloid and tau are used in the diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease. These were typically drawn from cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) which can be accessed via a lumbar puncture. However, this is impractical in the real world. Now, other scores like the C2N developed amyloid score are used. This score uses a patient’s ApoE variant, looks at the ratio of two variants of amyloid beta, and also looks at their age to predict the probability of Alzheimer's disease pathology.

title: Preventing Alzheimer's Disease
content: There are various strategies for preventing Alzheimer’s disease and neurodegeneration. Exercise is a potent tool, but there are also lesser-known factors that could impact brain health, such as nutrition supplementation, lipid management, brain games, sauna, oral health, and hearing loss. Modifiable behaviors that potentially play a role in risk reduction of neurodegeneration include smoking, alcohol, sleep, head injuries, and blood pressure. Nutrition also impacts brain health, with common diets, metabolic health, and energy balance playing a role. Supplements such as EPA and DHA, vitamin D, and B vitamins can also be beneficial.

title: Impact of Exercise on Brain Health
content: Exercise has a significant impact on brain health. The minimum effective dose and the most important types of exercise are still being researched.

title: Oral Health and Brain Health
content: Oral health has an association with brain health. Maintaining good oral health can potentially improve brain health and prevent neurodegeneration.

title: Reducing Lipids for Brain Health
content: Reducing lipids can improve brain health and prevent neurodegeneration. Lipid management is a key strategy in maintaining brain health.

title: Hearing Loss and Brain Health
content: Hearing loss can potentially impact brain health and neurodegeneration. It is important to address and manage hearing loss to maintain brain health.

title: Uncertainty about C2N Test
content: We have tremendous uncertainty about this C2N test, unlike, for example, ApoB, where we have really clear relationship between at least population risk and marker. But when it comes to this C2N test, we have to reserve this for people who are at the highest risk.

title: Genetic Component of Alzheimer’s Disease
content: There is a strong genetic component to Alzheimer’s disease. Several genes are implicated in this, but the three most penetrant genes are: PSEN1, PSEN2, and APP. These genes are as close to what we would call deterministic as any genes are. Fortunately, they are very rare and only account for 1% of AD cases. Those patients get Alzheimer’s disease very early—it’s not uncommon for these patients to be afflicted in their 50s.

title: Understanding your APOE Status
content: There are three alleles for the APOE gene. APOE is a gene which codes for a protein, unsurprisingly called ApoE. But we have three different versions of that gene circulating in our gene pool: E2 (most rare), E3 (most common), E4 (second most common). These genes can therefore be combined in up to six ways, because you’re going to get one copy from your mom and one copy from your dad.

title: Prevalence of Alzheimer’s Disease and Other Forms of Dementia
content: Globally, the prevalence of AD is 2 to 1 in favor of women to men—so women are literally twice as likely to get Alzheimer’s disease as men. Interestingly, we see the reverse in Parkinson’s disease.

title: Can the Risk of Alzheimer’s Disease be Decreased with Behavioral Changes?
content: The bulk of today’s AMA is going to be around: What are the measures that we can take? What are the modifiable behaviors that factor into risk reduction or prevention? Here’s the problem, it is really difficult to do this directly with control trials, given the time course. There are a couple of examples where we can pretty convincingly take a causal view, but unfortunately, much of the data here is epidemiologic.

title: Overview of Modifiable Behaviors that Potentially Play a Role in Risk Reduction of Neurodegeneration
content: We’re now going to spend the rest of this AMA with the true focus of what are these things that you can do to prevent Alzheimer’s dementia and work to keep your brain as healthy as possible? The most valuable thing would be to talk about the non-obvious things. We’ve got like 13 things on the list that we think play a role, potentially, in risk reduction.

title: Health Risks Associated with Smoking and Alcohol Consumption
content: Not smoking is better for your risk of Alzheimer’s. Less alcohol consumption is better for your risk. The risk of smoking to dementia is less than the risk of smoking to lung cancer and heart disease. However, we’re talking about a roughly 60% increase in the risk—so at any point in time, a smoker compared to a non-smoker is going to have about a 60% higher chance of all-cause dementia. Once you have quit for at least nine years, your risk falls to that of a non-smoker. There’s an alcohol paradox. Some people have claimed that there is a backwards J-shaped morbidity curve associated with alcohol. The lowest risk is at a couple drinks a week and then risk goes way up. But if you go down to no alcohol, risk goes up. It turns out that that’s almost entirely confounded by the population of people that are consuming zero alcohol.

title: Importance of Adequate Sleep for Health
content: Adequate sleep is better for risk. Sleep suffers from a lot of the epidemiologic baggage that comes with things that aren’t easy to study prospectively. But it’s easier epidemiologically to study than things like exercise and things like nutrition because the intervention itself is so straightforward and it’s generally much easier for people to recall how long they sleep than what they ate, for example. When it comes to Alzheimer’s disease risk, we’re seeing about a 60% increase when it comes to all-cause dementia, we’re seeing about a 20% increase for people who have disturbed sleep versus not disturbed sleep. When we start to get into short sleep, comparing people with less than five hours of sleep to people with more than seven hours of sleep, you’re talking about a hazard ratio of 2.6, meaning 160% difference in all-cause dementia.

title: Impact of Head Injuries on Health
content: Fewer head injuries is better for risk. Head injury is something we’re becoming much more aware of lately. It looks pretty clear that head injury does increase relative risk. The risk looks like it’s about an 80% increase for all comers. This includes repeated blows to the head and severe head injury.

title: Importance of Blood Pressure Control for Health
content: Well-controlled blood pressure is better for risk. We know that blood pressure plays a big role in vascular health and vascular health plays a big role in brain health. Anything that reduces blood flow, anything that reduces oxygenation, anything that reduces availability of nutrient is going to be very bad for the brain.

title: Impact of Nutrition on Brain Health
content: As we think about nutrition and as they think about brain health, what are the most important considerations they should think about there? There’s a fundamental problem here, which is not to suggest that nutrition isn’t important. The way we really want to go about answering this question is: we want to look at what the increase in risk is for patients who have type 2 diabetes. It’s very difficult to assume that that risk isn’t real, that it’s not causal. Then we want to ask the question: How big is that compared to the magnitude of the benefit from following any one of these “magical” diets? The implication of that is that not having diabetes, not being insulin-resistant and being in energy balance has more benefit than anything else. And therefore the right diet is whatever diet keeps you insulin-sensitive in energy balance, and obviously therefore, not having type 2 diabetes.
